article.title: Baryon Asymmetry and Gravitational Waves from Pseudoscalar Inflation

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the integral functions IEE, IBB, and IEB describe?
choices: The energy densities stored in the hyperelectric and hypermagnetic fields, respectively, and their cross term.
The evolution of the scale factor during inflation.
The strength of the axion-gauge-field coupling.
The baryon and lepton number densities.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the constraint δF ≤ 1 signify?
choices: The gauge field backreaction on the inflationary dynamics becomes significant.
The tensor-to-scalar ratio is bounded from above by the CMB observations.
The gauge field production during inflation is negligible.
The integral functions IEE, IBB, and IEB become insensitive to the UV cut-off scale.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the vertical dotted lines in the figure?
choices: They represent the time of electroweak symmetry breaking.
They represent the transition temperature from the adiabatic regime to the inverse cascade regime.
They represent the time of reheating after inflation.
They represent the time when the hypermagnetic field strength reaches its present-day value.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the physical interpretation of the green band in the figure?
choices: Region in parameter space where the gauge field production dominates the total energy density.
Region in parameter space where the tensor-to-scalar ratio exceeds the PLANCK constraint.
Region in parameter space where baryogenesis around the time of EWSB produces a baryon asymmetry consistent with the observed value.
Region in parameter space where the present-day magnetic field strength exceeds the observational upper limits.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure demonstrate about the relationship between the instability parameter ξ and the Hubble rate H?
choices: Successful baryogenesis only occurs for specific combinations of ξ and H.
Successful baryogenesis is independent of the values of ξ and H.
Increasing ξ always leads to successful baryogenesis, regardless of the value of H.
Decreasing H always leads to successful baryogenesis, regardless of the value of ξ.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the distinct peak in the present-day GW signal strength in certain regions of parameter space?
choices: The transition from the adiabatic regime to the inverse cascade regime of the primordial gauge fields.
The backreaction of the gauge fields on the inflationary dynamics, leading to a violation of slow-roll conditions.
The explosive production of gauge field quanta due to the anomalous coupling between the inflaton and the gauge field.
The decay of the primordial hypermagnetic field into the electromagnetic field during the electroweak crossover.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the implication of points located below the diagonal line in the figure?
choices: They correspond to scenarios where baryogenesis is successful.
They correspond to scenarios where the gauge field production is too weak to be relevant for the GW signal.
They correspond to scenarios where the GW signal peak is within the sensitivity reach of current or upcoming GW interferometers.
They correspond to scenarios where the reheating temperature is lower than the electroweak scale.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different trajectories in the ξ–H parameter plane represent?
choices: Different stages of the postinflationary evolution of the universe.
Different models of pseudoscalar inflation with varying axion-gauge-field coupling strengths.
Different scenarios of reheating after inflation.
Different possible evolutions of the weak mixing angle during the electroweak crossover.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why do the GW spectra of models A and B exhibit a peak at the very end of inflation?
choices: Because the scalar power spectrum peaks at the same time.
Because the reheating temperature is maximized at the end of inflation.
Because the instability parameter ξ reaches its maximum value at the end of inflation, leading to strong gauge field production.
Because the inverse cascade regime of the hypermagnetic field ends at the same time.
